translation.en: [woman 1] At the moment of death.
are we actually just dead or is something else going on?
translation.ko: 우린 정말로 죽는 걸까요, 아니면 다른 뭔가가 일어나는 걸까요?

translation.en: [man 1] There's no one on the planet who doesn't have a vested interest
translation.ko: 이 질문에 관심이 없는 사람은 세상에 없습니다

translation.en: in the question, does life go on after death?
[man 2] Whatever this consciousness is that we have in this life...
it was also there in another life before.
translation.ko: 그 의식은 이전에 다른 생에서도 있었습니다

translation.en: [woman 2] He said, "Mom, I think I need to tell you somethin'.
I think I used to be somebody else."
[woman 3] How many people here have had a near-death experience?
translation.ko: 여러분 중에 임사 체험을 해보신 분 있어요?

translation.en: Lotta dead people here today. Welcome.
translation.ko: 죽은 분이 많이 오셨네요 어서 오세요

translation.en: We had to rethink everything that we believed about death and dying.
translation.ko: 죽음과 죽는다는 것에 대한 모든 생각을 재고해야 했죠

translation.en: [woman 4] There have always been ghosts in history.
We continue to report them and see them.
To the spirits of the mansion, help us connect more deeply to your world.
translation.ko: 저택의 혼령들이여 당신들의 세계에 더 깊이 접속하도록 도와주소서

translation.en: Is there a child on the other side connected to you?
translation.ko: 반대편 세계에 당신과 관련된 아이가 있나요?

translation.en: Yes.
[man 3] There are things that science can't test.
translation.ko: 과학이 시험할 수 없는 것들이 있습니다

translation.en: It doesn't mean they don't happen.
Literally, I can feel him and I know that he is there with me right now.
translation.ko: 그 사람을 느낄 수 있고 지금 저와 있다는 걸 알아요

translation.en: [woman 5] I could feel my spirit sort of peeling away from my body.
translation.ko: 제 영혼이 몸에서 벗겨져 나가는 느낌이 들었어요

translation.en: How good would it be to know there is life after death?
translation.ko: 사후에 생이 있단 걸 알면 얼마나 좋을까요?

translation.en: [woman] As a physician, I know that most people don't think about death really
translation.ko: 의사인 저는 대부분의 사람들이 죽음이 임박해서야

translation.en: until they're forced to.
But 20 years ago, I was not only physically dead,
translation.ko: 근데 20년 전에 저는 신체적으로 죽었을 뿐 아니라

translation.en: I had been dead for a while.
translation.ko: 정말로 한참 동안 죽었던 적이 있어요

translation.en: And that experience radically changed
translation.ko: 그리고 그 경험으로 인해 내가 누군지에 대한 모든 생각이

translation.en: everything about what I am and who I am.
translation.ko: 그리고 그 경험으로 인해 내가 누군지에 대한 모든 생각이 근본적으로 바뀌었죠 "메리 닐, 의학박사 척추정형외과"

translation.en: In 1999, I arranged to go to Chile and kayak.
And I was looking forward
translation.ko: 그 강에서 폭포로 유명한 구역이 있었는데

translation.en: to this section of river that's well known for its waterfalls.
translation.ko: 그 강에서 폭포로 유명한 구역이 있었는데 무척 기대가 컸죠

translation.en: We put on the river and we went over the first couple of drops.
translation.ko: 우린 강에 올랐고 처음 두어 번의 폭포수를 잘 넘었어요

translation.en: This river has a very high flow.
So we decided to run this smaller part of the first major waterfall.
translation.ko: 그래서 첫 번째 주 폭포의 상대적으로 작은 물줄기 쪽으로 가기로 했어요

translation.en: And so I pulled out in the current.
There was another kayaker who had sort of bobbled her way past.
translation.ko: 근데 이미 불안정하게 타며 지나간 사람이 있었는데

translation.en: And her boat was lodged sideways at the entrance.
translation.ko: 그녀의 배가 입구에 옆으로 누어 박혀 있었어요

translation.en: So I was forced over to the main part of the waterfall.
translation.ko: 그래서 제가 폭포의 그 주요 부분으로 가야 했죠

translation.en: [laughing] I mean, I-- I knew it was not gonna be good!
translation.ko: 왠지 좋지 않을 거란 걸 알았어요

translation.en: My boat became pinned and I was completely submerged under ten feet of water.
translation.ko: 제 배는 꼼짝없이 끼어버렸고 전 물속 3m 아래로 잠겼죠

translation.en: I was not breathing.
My torso was absolutely plastered to the front deck of the boat.
translation.ko: 몸통은 배 앞쪽 데크에 완전히 붙어버렸습니다

translation.en: I could feel my bones breaking.
I thought I should be screaming, but I wasn't.
translation.ko: 소리를 질러야 한다고 생각했지만 그럴 수 없었죠

translation.en: I felt... uh, no pain, no fear, no panic.
translation.ko: 아무런 아픔도 두려움도 고통도 안 느껴졌어요

translation.en: I felt more alive than I've ever felt.
translation.ko: 그 어느 때보다 살아있단 느낌이 들었죠

translation.en: I could feel my spirit sort of peeling away from my body,
translation.ko: 제 영혼이 몸에서 벗겨져 나가는 게 느껴졌고

translation.en: and my spirit was then released up to the heavens.
I was immediately greeted by a group of somethings.
I don't know what to call them. People, spirits, beings.
translation.ko: 일컬을 말을 모르겠네요 사람, 혼령, 존재...

translation.en: I didn't recognize any of them.
But they had been important in my life story somehow.
Like a grandparent who died before I was born.
translation.ko: 제가 태어나기 전에 돌아가셨던 할아버지, 이런 식으로요

translation.en: They were so overjoyed to welcome me and greet me and love me.
translation.ko: 그들은 너무나 기뻐하며 저를 맞았고 애정을 표현했어요

translation.en: These beings started taking me down this pathway.
translation.ko: 그리고 저를 데리고 어떤 길을 따라가기 시작했어요

translation.en: The pathway was very thickly covered with hundreds of thousands of flowers,
translation.ko: 그 길은 헤아릴 수 없이 많은 꽃들로 뒤덮여 있었고

translation.en: and the aromas of flowers.
It was exploding with every color of the universe.
translation.ko: 그리고 우주의 온갖 색채를 띠며 폭발하고 있었고요

translation.en: There was an absolute shift of time and dimension.
I experienced all of eternity in every second,
translation.ko: 전 매 순간 영원의 모든 걸 경험했어요

translation.en: and every second expanded into all of eternity.
translation.ko: 그리고 매 순간은 영원의 모든 것 속으로 확장됐고요

translation.en: The pathway went to this great domed structure.
translation.ko: 그 길은 멋진 돔형 구조물로 이어졌어요

translation.en: I believe I was in heaven.
God's world, whatever you wanna call it.
I had an overwhelming sense of being home.
At the same time, I could look back at the river,
translation.ko: 그와 동시에 강을 내려다볼 수 있었는데

translation.en: where my body was still submerged under water.
translation.ko: 제 몸은 여전히 물속에 잠겨 있었죠

translation.en: [man yells] You okay?
[woman] The group of kayakers kept trying to get to me,
translation.ko: 함께 간 동료들이 제게 오려고 애를 썼지만

translation.en: but they were never able to do it.
And after maybe 15 minutes, they had given up rescue.
translation.ko: 그리고 15분 정도 지나자 그들은 구조를 포기했어요

translation.en: They had really shifted over into a body recovery mode.
One of the guys saw my life jacket pop up downstream
translation.ko: 그중 한 명이 제 구명조끼가 떠내려가는 걸 봤어요

translation.en: and thought that maybe my husband would want it.
translation.ko: 그는 제 남편이 그걸 원할지도 모른단 생각을 했고

translation.en: As he got that, he felt my body hit his leg.
translation.ko: 그걸 가지러 가면서 다리로 제 몸을 부딪쳤어요

translation.en: So he reached underwater and was able to grab my wrist.
translation.ko: 그래서 물속에 손을 넣었고 제 손목을 잡았죠

translation.en: My body was bloated and purple and I had fixed eyes.
translation.ko: 제 몸은 부풀어 오르고 보라색으로 변해갔고 눈은 고정돼 있었어요

translation.en: There's absolutely no doubt...
in my own mind that I was physically dead.
But I watched from the entrance to the domed structure
translation.ko: 전 돔형 구조물 입구에서 그들이 심폐소생술을 시작하는 걸

translation.en: as they started CPR, and I could still hear them.
translation.ko: 전 돔형 구조물 입구에서 그들이 심폐소생술을 시작하는 걸 보고 들을 수 있었어요

translation.en: One of the guys kept calling to me to come back and take a breath.
translation.ko: 한 남자가 계속 저더러 정신 차리라며, 숨을 쉬라고 했죠

translation.en: You know, "Please come back. I know you're still here."
translation.ko: '정신 차려요 아직 여기 있는 거 알아요'

translation.en: I had been without oxygen for 30 minutes,
translation.ko: 전 산소를 30분 동안 들이마시지 못한 상태였어요

translation.en: and the statistical likelihood of my survival should have been zero.
I did not want to go back down to my body.
I had a very, very physical sensation of being held and comforted
translation.ko: 안락하게 안겨 있다는 신체적인 느낌이 강하게 들었고

translation.en: and reassured that everything was fine.
But the beings told me that it wasn't my time,
translation.ko: 그런데 그 존재들은 제가 올 때가 아니라고 했죠

translation.en: that I had more work to do on Earth,
translation.ko: 지상에서 할 일이 아직 더 있다고요

translation.en: and that I had to go back to my body.
When I opened my eyes, the guys that resuscitated me
translation.ko: 눈을 뜨자 제게 인공호흡을 해준 사람들은

translation.en: were stunned.
I was in terrible shape.
[laughs] I mean, I had just drowned.
But I also had, uh... multiple broken bones and torn ligaments in my legs.
translation.ko: 게다가 여러 군데 뼈도 부러졌고 다리에 인대들도 찢어졌죠

translation.en: And I was...
on the side of a river in the middle of nowhere.
The guys who resuscitated me put my body on top of a boat
translation.ko: 그들은 저를 배의 윗부분에 옮긴 다음

translation.en: and then began to try to get me up the hillside.
We emerged onto a dirt road.
They thought maybe someone would run and get a tractor, a horse or something.
translation.ko: 그들은 달려가서 트랙터든 말이든 뭐든 잡을 생각이었어요

translation.en: But when we emerged onto the dirt road,
exactly there was an ambulance, which
in 1999, in southern Chile, didn't exist. [laughs]
It was inexplicable.
It took a number of hours, but my friends got me to the hospital.
translation.ko: 몇 시간이 걸렸지만 동료들은 절 병원으로 옮겼죠

translation.en: My husband was actually told that...
I probably would not survive the night.
But I did.
I was in the hospital for more than a month.
translation.ko: 전 한 달 이상 병원에 입원했고

translation.en: I had... several operations.
Then many, many months of rehab before I could walk again.
translation.ko: 그리고 수개월의 재활 훈련 끝에 다시 걸을 수 있게 됐어요

translation.en: And statistically, I had zero likelihood
translation.ko: 통계적으로는 뇌 손상 없이 생존할 가능성이

translation.en: of surviving without significant brain damage.
translation.ko: 통계적으로는 뇌 손상 없이 생존할 가능성이 전혀 없었죠

translation.en: But I never actually had any brain damage.
translation.ko: 하지만 전 어떤 뇌 손상도 입지 않았어요

translation.en: [laughing] My kids might say something differently, but...
made a complete recovery.
As a physician, I'm not really in a crowd of people
translation.ko: 의사인 제 주변엔 임사 체험 같은 종류의 얘기를 하고 싶어 하는 사람이

translation.en: who want to talk about things like near death experiences.
translation.ko: 임사 체험 같은 종류의 얘기를 하고 싶어 하는 사람이 별로 없습니다

translation.en: People in science often think you can't possibly believe in anything supernatural.
translation.ko: 과학계 사람들은 초자연적인 건 믿을 수 없다고들 하니까요

translation.en: When I went off to medical school,
I would have defined death as...
death, meaning physical death.
But my near-death experience,
and then what happened to my son ten years later,
translation.ko: 그 10년 후 제 아들에게 일어난 일을 계기로

translation.en: changed my definition of death significantly.
translation.ko: 죽음에 대한 저의 정의는 상당히 바뀌게 됐죠

translation.en: I don't believe that...
we... know everything. [laughs]
[man] A near death experience, sometimes called an NDE,
is a profound experience that many people have
translation.ko: 많은 사람들이 죽음에 임박했을 때 하는

translation.en: when they come close to death.
Probably between ten and 20% of people whose hearts actually stop
will report these dramatic near-death experiences.
translation.ko: "정신의학 & 신경 행동과학 명예교수" 이런 극적인 임사 체험을 한다고 하죠

translation.en: Here at the Division of Perceptual Studies,
we study the possibility that something about humans
translation.ko: 인간과 관련한 어떤 것이 육체적 죽음 이후에도

translation.en: may survive bodily death.
translation.ko: 생존할 수 있다는 가능성에 관해 연구합니다

translation.en: [man 2] The general mainstream, materialist view of reality
is that physical matter is all there is.
So when the physical brain stops working, then the consciousness ends.
translation.ko: 그렇기에 뇌라는 물리적 기관이 작동을 멈추면 의식은 끝난다는 겁니다

translation.en: So the idea that there might be this consciousness piece that could continue on
translation.ko: 그래서 그런 의식의 일부가 지속될 수도 있다는 개념은

translation.en: conflicts with a pretty basic principle.
But the question of what happens after we die
is something that has intrigued humans for as long as we've been around.
translation.ko: "짐 터커, 의학박사 지각 과학부 학부장" 태초부터 인류의 흥미를 끌어온 질문이죠

translation.en: [Bruce] We've been doing this research for almost 50 years now.
translation.ko: 우리는 이 연구를 거의 50년 동안 해왔습니다

translation.en: We study mediums,
people who think they can communicate with the deceased.
We've studied deathbed visions that happen to people as they die.
translation.ko: 사람들이 죽을 때 보는 임종 환영을 연구하고

translation.en: We've studied reincarnation
and a variety of other spontaneously occurring experiences
translation.ko: 그리고 임사 체험처럼 삶과 죽음의 경계에서

translation.en: on the border between life and death, such as near-death experiences.
translation.ko: 자연적으로 발생하는 다양한 경험에 관해서도 연구하죠

translation.en: If you look back in history,
there have been what we now call near death experiences
since prehistoric times.
But the first collection of near-death experiences
translation.ko: 하지만 그것들을 처음으로 정리해서 발표한 건

translation.en: was put together in 1892 by Albert Heim,
a geologist in Switzerland.
While climbing in the Alps, he had fallen...
translation.ko: 그는 알프스산맥을 오르던 도중 추락한 적이 있는데

translation.en: and had a beautiful experience as he was falling down the mountain.
translation.ko: 그때 아주 굉장한 경험을 했던 것입니다

translation.en: He described time expanding as he went faster and faster.
translation.ko: 그는 점점 빨리 떨어지는 동안의 시간 확장에 대해 묘사했습니다

translation.en: And he was so struck by this experience
that he started asking other mountain climbers,
and quickly collected 30 other cases like his
of people who had falls from great heights who had blissful experiences.
translation.ko: 행복한 경험을 한 이들의 사례를 금세 30건이나 수집했죠

translation.en: And then in the 1960s and '70s,
resuscitation medicine really got started.
[man] External chest compression is the best rescue technique
translation.ko: 구조 기술 중 인공 순환에 가장 효과적인 건

translation.en: for artificial circulation.
[Bruce] Which means we were bringing people back
translation.ko: 죽음의 문턱에 간 사람들을 점점 더 많이

translation.en: from the brink of death in larger and larger numbers.
translation.ko: 죽음의 문턱에 간 사람들을 점점 더 많이 데려오게 됐다는 거죠

translation.en: Many people came back and reported these blissful experiences
translation.ko: 많은 사람들이 돌아와서 육신을 떠나 다른 영역에 갔던

translation.en: in which they left their bodies and traveled to some other realm.
Patients say they become aware of what's described as a tunnel...
translation.ko: 제대로 인식하게 됐다고 환자들은 말하죠 기존에 들어봤던 터널이나

translation.en: a passageway, a portal.
translation.ko: "레이먼드 무디, 의학박사 1998년" 통로, 포털이란 거에 대해서요

translation.en: And they go into this tunnel...
and when they come out,
they come out into a very brilliant, warm, loving and accepting light.
translation.ko: 아주 밝고, 따뜻하고, 사랑 넘치고 수용적인 빛이 가득한 곳인 거죠

translation.en: [Bruce] In 1975, Raymond Moody wrote his book Life After Life,
which caused many people, myself included,
to take near death experiences more seriously.
translation.ko: 임사 체험을 더욱 진지하게 받아들이는 계기가 됐습니다

translation.en: [man] When Raymond Moody's book came out,
I thought that near death experiences were rubbish.
Had to be.
And they occurred in the United States, in California and that's the end of it.
translation.ko: 그건 미국 캘리포니아에서 일어난 일일 뿐이었어요

translation.en: Would it ever cross to England?
No. We're far too sensible to have experiences like this.
translation.ko: 아뇨, 우린 그런 경험을 하기엔 너무 이성적인 사람들이니까요

translation.en: But I'm a neuropsychiatrist,
and, one day, this guy walked into my consulting room.
translation.ko: 어느 날 어떤 사람이 저의 진료실을 찾았습니다

translation.en: He'd just had a cardiac catheter go wrong,
left his body, watched the resuscitation process,
and had a full near-death experience.
And so there I was, confronted. Did I believe or did I not?
translation.ko: 그렇게 대면했는데 전 믿었을까요, 안 믿었을까요?

translation.en: Well, I thought that before I could draw any conclusions,
translation.ko: 전 어떤 식으로든 결론을 내리기 전에

translation.en: that I ought to study them.
So I've been studying near death experiences for about 40 years.
translation.ko: 그렇게 해서 지금까지 40년간 임사 체험을 연구 중입니다

translation.en: The science we have, which is a materialistic science,
says it's all brain.
All brain.
So when the brain stops functioning, you can't be conscious.
translation.ko: 그렇기에 뇌가 그 기능을 멈추면 사람은 의식을 할 수 없습니다

translation.en: But during a near death experience,
you get these very wide expansions of consciousness,
even when the brain has ceased to function.
translation.ko: 뇌가 그 기능을 멈췄을 때도 말이죠

translation.en: So it can't be all brain.
translation.ko: 그러니 전부 뇌와 관련된 게 아닌 겁니다

translation.en: [Bruce] Near death experiences are subjective experiences...
that are very difficult to confirm objectively.
And that raises questions in the minds of many scientists.
Some of the critics of this research complain that this is just anecdotes.
translation.ko: 이 연구에 대한 비평 중 일부에선 단지 일화일 뿐이라고 합니다

translation.en: Well, actually, if you look at the history of science,
all science starts as collecting anecdotes,
and then finding patterns among those different stories.
translation.ko: 그러다 그 다른 이야기들 사이에서 패턴을 찾죠

translation.en: And there are millions of these experiences
translation.ko: 그리고 임사 체험에 관해선 전 세계에서 수백만 건이

translation.en: being reported across the globe.
translation.ko: 그리고 임사 체험에 관해선 전 세계에서 수백만 건이 보고돼 있어요

translation.en: [woman 1] I was experiencing a really bad asthma attack in my apartment.
translation.ko: 집에 있는데 굉장히 심한 천식 발작이 일어났어요

translation.en: [man] I was blown up by a bomb in the Vietnam War
translation.ko: 베트남전 참전 당시 가까이에서 폭탄이 터졌고

translation.en: and then shot through the arm, chest and neck.
[woman 2] I was hit broadside by a woman who was texting while she was driving.
translation.ko: 운전 중에 문자를 보내던 여자가 제 차의 측면을 들이받았어요

translation.en: [man 2] I hit my head, broke my neck, injured my spinal cord
translation.ko: 머리가 부딪치고 목이 부러지고 척수가 손상돼

translation.en: and was paralyzed right away.
[Bruce] I've been doing this work for four decades now,
and what I've found is that, no matter how you come close to death
translation.ko: 그리고 알아낸 것이 있는데 죽음에 어떻게 가까이 갔든

translation.en: there are very consistent patterns in the experience itself...
translation.ko: 그 경험 자체와 사람들에게 영향을 주는 방식엔

translation.en: and in how it affects people.
For example, people all over the world will report
translation.ko: 예를 들어 세계 어느 곳의 사람이건

translation.en: that their sense of time was distorted.
For me, there was no sense of time.
translation.ko: - 전 시간 감각이 없어졌었어요 - 찰나, 혹은 수개월, 수천 년

translation.en: Moments or months or millennia. I don't know.
translation.ko: - 전 시간 감각이 없어졌었어요 - 찰나, 혹은 수개월, 수천 년 - 모르겠어요 - 얼마라고 말할 순 없지만

translation.en: I had no idea how fast it was going,
but it was light speed.
[Bruce] They also describe this warm, loving being of light.
translation.ko: 또한 따뜻하고 사랑이 넘치는 빛의 존재도 말합니다

translation.en: A sense of getting information from some really high-frequency teachers.
translation.ko: 굉장히 고주파인 선생님한테 정보를 받는 느낌이었어요

translation.en: Very embracing and warm and-- and caressing.
translation.ko: 무척 포용해주고 따뜻하고 어루만져 주는 느낌이었죠

translation.en: A warm energy hug...
to the brain.
[Bruce] And then there are things that are paranormal or otherworldly.
Like your ordinary senses becoming much more vivid.
translation.ko: 예를 들어 감각이 평소보다 훨씬 생생해진다고 하죠

translation.en: All this grand music.
Jacques Cousteau. [laughs]
Being under the water and all these fish.
I started dissolving, or, like that drop into the ocean, just disappearing.
translation.ko: 녹기 시작했죠 바닷속의 물방울처럼 사라졌다고 할까요

translation.en: If I could reach out and touch a leaf...
I became an aspect of that leaf.
translation.ko: 그 잎의 한 부분이 될 것 같았어요

translation.en: I was a tiny, tiny light, a little tiny speck of light,
translation.ko: 전 아주 작은 빛이었어요 아주 작은 빛의 입자였다가 멋지고 커다란 빛이 됐죠

translation.en: and then I'd become a great, big light.
translation.ko: 아주 작은 빛의 입자였다가 멋지고 커다란 빛이 됐죠

translation.en: [Bruce] You'll see the same phenomena from all different cultures.
translation.ko: 서로 다른 문화권의 사람들이지만 같은 현상을 봅니다

translation.en: And they often come back feeling that it profoundly changed them.
translation.ko: 그리고 그로 인한 심오한 변화를 느끼며 돌아오죠

translation.en: [woman 3] I see the beauty in everything now.
[woman 4] A hundred percent turnaround from being a hardcore, angry atheist.
[woman 2] I no longer have any kind of a fear of death.
translation.ko: 죽음에 대한 어떤 종류의 두려움도 없어요

translation.en: [Bruce] What is going on here
that has such power to change a person's life in a fraction of a second?
translation.ko: 한 사람의 인생을 바꿀 힘을 지닌 어떤 일이 일어나는 걸까요? "1. 사고의 변화 2. 감정의 변화"

translation.en: [woman 1] Hi, everybody.
-[woman 2] Hi. -[group] Hey.
This is the Seattle International Association for Near-Death Studies.
translation.ko: 여기는 국제 임사 체험 학회 시애틀 지부입니다

translation.en: How many people here, by show of hands, have had a near death experience?
translation.ko: 임사 체험을 해보신 분 손들어 주시겠어요?

translation.en: A lot of dead people here today. Welcome! [laughs]
translation.ko: 죽은 분이 많이 오셨네요 어서 오세요

translation.en: Near death experiences are not just butterflies and flowers
translation.ko: 임사 체험에는 꼭 나비와 꽃과 "킴벌리 클라크 샤프 의료 사회 복지사"

translation.en: and God and light and heaven.
translation.ko: "킴벌리 클라크 샤프 의료 사회 복지사" 신과 빛과 천국이 등장하는 건 아니에요

translation.en: You will find that you have difficulties with materialism.
translation.ko: 기존의 물질주의에 문제가 생긴 걸 알게 되죠

translation.en: Maybe with employment.
Probably with your marriage, if you're married.
Because the changes are so profound.
So I began counseling people with near death experiences.
translation.ko: 그래서 전 임사 체험자들에게 상담을 해주기 시작했죠

translation.en: And I have the advantage of having had a near death experience,
so I can honestly say, "I know how you feel."
translation.ko: 솔직히 말할 수 있어요 '당신이 어떤 기분인 줄 알아요'

translation.en: -I'm good. -Yeah?
-Have a seat. -Thank you.
[woman] I didn't just go into cardiac arrest.
translation.ko: 전 그냥 심정지 상태가 된 게 아니에요

translation.en: My electrolytes...
flip-flopped.
I was basically poisoned.
And I was gone.
When I came back, it pulled me away from a lot of people.
translation.ko: 돌아왔을 땐 많은 사람들과 거리가 생겼어요

translation.en: It's hard to even talk to my husband...
because I feel that...
somebody is going to bring a straitjacket and throw away the key.
Because what I used to know is not what I know now.
translation.ko: 예전에 알던 것과 지금 아는 게 다르니까요

translation.en: And I'm havin' a very hard time with it.
translation.ko: 그래서 몹시 힘든 시간을 보내고 있어요

translation.en: Yeah. Feeling crazy... I'm validating you.
translation.ko: 네, 미친 것 같은 그 기분 나는 잘 알아요

translation.en: ...is part of the adjustment,
because everything gets so mixed up.
You died.
-[laughs] -You had an experience.
You came back and now you have to live in the same world,
but with a completely different point of view.
And it's so hard when everybody else's point of view hasn't changed.
translation.ko: 저 외의 모든 사람들의 시각은 안 바뀌었으니 너무 힘들어요

translation.en: Seattle IANDS is a place of comfort and hope,
validation and support, and I hope attending here...
calms your heart and your emotions...
and reminds you that this is a very temporary situation.
translation.ko: 이건 아주 일시적인 상황이란 게 상기되길 바랍니다

translation.en: Life.
People attend Seattle IANDS because they've had a near death experience.
translation.ko: 사람들은 임사 체험을 했기에 시애틀 IANDS에 참석해요

translation.en: People come because they're grieving and want to hear that we go on.
translation.ko: 힘들기에, 그리고 남들이 겪는 걸 듣고 싶기에 옵니다

translation.en: And then people come just to hear it's real,
translation.ko: 그리고 이게 진짜란 걸 듣고 싶어서 오고요

translation.en: it really happened, and has happened to millions of people.
translation.ko: 실제로 일어난 일이고 수백만 명의 사람들이 겪은 일입니다

translation.en: My experience started...
incredibly enough, on a Wednesday evening.
And it was Thanksgiving coming up the next day.
And we were running some electrical lines on some poles...
translation.ko: 몇몇 기둥에 전선을 놓는 작업을 하는 중이었고

translation.en: and I was up on a bucket truck.
We kind of said, "We could save a couple of hours if I stay up on the bucket...
translation.ko: 이렇게 말했죠, '시간을 절약하자 내가 계속 버킷에서 작업하고'

translation.en: and you just maneuver the truck...
from space to space."
I hit the side of the bucket and I broke all my ribs on my right side.
translation.ko: 전 버킷의 측면에 부딪쳤고 오른쪽 갈비뼈가 다 부러졌어요

translation.en: I wound up in an emergency room.
They gave me a medication for pain...
and it had some kind of an anti-inflammatory component.
Turns out I'm allergic to it.
translation.ko: 알고 보니 제가 그거에 알레르기가 있었죠

translation.en: So, ultimately, my lungs shut down, I stopped breathing and my heart stopped.
translation.ko: 결국 폐가 작동을 멈췄고 호흡도 심장도 멈췄어요

translation.en: There was a tunnel, but not the way that it's typically described.
translation.ko: 터널이 하나 있었는데 흔히 말하는 종류는 아니었어요

translation.en: I kind of fell into it.
And what I saw was just color...
wrapped all around me, so that I was completely integrated into it.
translation.ko: 저를 온통 감쌌어요 그래서 완전히 그것에 흡수됐죠

translation.en: And I could hear this color talking to me. Millions of voices.
translation.ko: 그리고 그 색은 제게 수백만 개의 목소리로 말했어요

translation.en: -"Sssss." This chatter. -[whispering voices]
Then I look down and I see the ocean.
translation.ko: 그런 다음에 아래를 봤는데 바다가 보였죠

translation.en: And then I notice a man in the water.
translation.ko: 그리고 한 남자도 있었어요 무릎 정도까지 잠기는 물속에 있었죠

translation.en: He's about knee deep.
Then he turns around suddenly.
And, uh...
the biggest surprise of my death, my new life...
translation.ko: 저의 그 죽음 혹은 새 삶에서 가장 놀라운 건

translation.en: was that it was my father.
Me and my dad had a very difficult relationship in life.
translation.ko: 아버지는 생전에 저와 무척 힘든 사이였어요

translation.en: We couldn't even hug.
So when he died, I felt totally bitter
translation.ko: 그래서 아버지가 돌아가셨을 때 우리가 서로 사랑한단 말을 하고 살지 못했단 사실이

translation.en: and really regretful of the fact
translation.ko: 우리가 서로 사랑한단 말을 하고 살지 못했단 사실이

translation.en: that we never were able to say we love each other or we care.
So I'm lookin' at him here in this space, and I'm saying, "Oh, my gosh.
translation.ko: 그 공간에 있는 아버지를 보며 말했죠, '맙소사'

translation.en: This is my opportunity.
My second chance to make peace with my dad."
translation.ko: '아버지와 화해할 수 있는 두 번째 기회다'

translation.en: Something that I could never do in life.
So...
we hugged.
[crying] And we said we loved each other. We loved each other.
That has changed my life in so many ways.
translation.ko: 그건 제 인생을 많은 면에서 바꿔 놓았습니다

translation.en: Just knowing that he did care.
translation.ko: 아버지가 날 아꼈다는 사실을 아는 것만으로도요

translation.en: That he did...
love me.
He looked at me when he embraced me. And he let go and he just looked at me.
translation.ko: 날 안아준 후에 쳐다보셨어요 팔을 풀고 쳐다봤죠

translation.en: He said, "Jose. You need to go back."
I'm lookin' at him, like, "What? Are you kidding me?
I like it here. This is great. I don't wanna go back."
And he said to me, "No, you gotta go back."
Whilst I didn't want to, uh...
we came to, kind of, sort of an agreement, in a way.
We-- we agreed that, when my time came, he would come get me and I said...
translation.ko: 때가 되면 아버지가 절 데리러 오겠다고요, 전 말했죠

translation.en: "Well, that sounds like a pretty good deal. Let me go with that."
And-- and I transitioned back.
I felt this sense of pull and I wound up back in my body.
translation.ko: 잡아당겨지는 느낌이 든 후에 제 몸에 돌아왔죠

translation.en: When I met my dad on the other side...
I realized that...
sometimes, we may not be able to say something here...
translation.ko: 우린 해야 할 얘기를 이곳에서 못 할 때가 있어요

translation.en: but...
we're gonna be able to say it somewhere else.
translation.ko: 다른 어떤 곳에서 말할 수 있게 돼요

translation.en: By having this opportunity...
it truly healed my spirit.
Before, I just was moving through life.
I wasn't living.
-I was not alive. -[applause]
Thank you.
[Bruce] There have been a number of medical explanations
that have been proposed to explain what causes near-death experiences.
I'm all in favor of that. Being a doctor, I wanna understand what causes these things.
translation.ko: 전 의사이기 때문에 그런 식으로 이유를 파헤치고 싶죠

translation.en: Unfortunately, I don't think any of the explanations we've come up with so far
translation.ko: 하지만 안타깝게도 지금까지는 그 어떤 것도 그것의 이해에

translation.en: help us very much in trying to understand things.
translation.ko: 큰 도움이 돼 주질 못한 것 같습니다

translation.en: Some have said drugs given to people as they're approaching death
translation.ko: 죽음이 임박한 사람들이 복용한 약 때문에

translation.en: may cause near death experiences.
translation.ko: 임사 체험이 유발된다고 말하는 이들도 있습니다

translation.en: And what we find is that the fewer drugs people are given...
the more likely they are to report a near death experience.
translation.ko: 임사 체험을 더 하게 된다는 게 밝혀졌죠

translation.en: That the drugs tend to inhibit the near-death experience,
rather than causing it.
People also suggest lack of oxygen to the brain.
translation.ko: 또 다른 원인으로 제기되는 건 뇌로 가는 산소의 부족입니다

translation.en: And that's appealing, because no matter how you come close to death,
translation.ko: 그 부분엔 솔깃해지죠 어떻게 죽음의 문턱에 갔든

translation.en: lack of oxygen to the brain is the common factor.
However, we know, from decades of research,
translation.ko: 하지만 저희는 수십 년 간의 연구를 통해

translation.en: what happens when you get lack of oxygen.
translation.ko: 뇌에 산소가 부족할 때의 현상을 잘 압니다

translation.en: People become frightened, become belligerent,
become terrified of what's happening to them.
Very much unlike the calm, consistent,
almost blissful experience of a near death experience.
I'm frequently challenged by people who say,
"Okay, he's had a cardiac arrest.
There's a little bit of brain which is working,
which you guys have all missed."
But this says that they don't really understand what consciousness is.
translation.ko: 하지만 그 말은 의식이 뭔지 제대로 모른다는 뜻입니다

translation.en: You cannot maintain consciousness
unless you have a highly-organized brain.
Believe you me, when the brain loses its oxygen,
-it doesn't organize itself. -[rhythmic bleeping]
[Bruce] When the heart stops, -in 20 seconds or so... -[continuous bleep]
translation.ko: 심장이 멈추면 20초 이내에 심장박동기가 일직선이 되는데

translation.en: ...you get flatlining, which means no brain activity.
translation.ko: 심장이 멈추면 20초 이내에 심장박동기가 일직선이 되는데 그건 뇌 활동이 없다는 뜻이죠

translation.en: And yet people have near death experiences
translation.ko: 그런데 임사 체험은 그보다 더 오래 죽어 있는 동안 하게 됩니다

translation.en: when they've been, quote, "flatlined" for longer than that.
translation.ko: 그보다 더 오래 죽어 있는 동안 하게 됩니다

translation.en: One of the most widely publicized cases was that of Pam Reynolds,
translation.ko: 가장 널리 알려진 것 중 하나는 팸 레이놀즈의 사례입니다

translation.en: who had an aneurysm,
which is a ballooning of a blood vessel at the base of her brain.
And it was so large that, if it burst, it would have killed her instantly.
translation.ko: 터지면 즉사할 정도로 그 크기가 몹시 컸죠

translation.en: The most that they could do for me was try...
a surgical process which involved the stopping of the heart,
the lowering of the bodily temperature,
the emptying of the blood from the body,
thereby shrinking the aneurysm.
translation.ko: 그래야 팽창된 동맥을 줄일 수 있죠

translation.en: [Bruce] She was without any blood going to her brain for about an hour.
translation.ko: 약 1시간가량 그녀의 뇌에는 혈액 공급이 안 됐습니다

translation.en: The EEG, or the brainwave, goes totally flat.
There is no brain activity at all.
Which presumably means there's no brain function at all during that time.
translation.ko: 추정컨대 그 시간 동안 뇌는 기능을 전혀 하지 않죠

translation.en: And yet, she reported a blissful near-death experience
translation.ko: 근데 그분은 정말 행복한 임사 체험을 하며

translation.en: in which she saw and heard things going on in the operating room
translation.ko: 수술실에서 일어나는 일을 보고 들을 수 있었어요

translation.en: that she couldn't possibly have seen or heard.
[Pam] My vantage point was rather like sitting on the shoulder of the surgeon.
translation.ko: 전 의사의 어깨쯤에서 내려다보는 것 같았습니다

translation.en: And I was free to move around at will.
While I knew what they were doing,
they didn't know what I was doing.
They thought I was that thing lying on the table.
translation.ko: 수술대 위에 누워있는 그게 저라고 생각했죠

translation.en: [Bruce] Now, her eyes were taped shut for the entire procedure,
and she had molded earpieces in her ears.
But she described the tools they were using to saw through her skull,
translation.ko: 하지만 팸은 두개골을 뚫는 데에 사용된 도구를 묘사했는데

translation.en: and it was something that she hadn't seen before or after.
translation.ko: 그전에도 그 후에도 본 적 없는 것들이었죠

translation.en: [Pam] I saw, in Dr. Spetzler's hand,
an instrument that reminded me suspiciously of an electric toothbrush.
translation.ko: 전동 칫솔을 연상시키는 어떤 도구를 봤어요

translation.en: There was a case very close to it, and it had bits...
that looked like the...
case that my father kept his socket wrenches in.
translation.ko: 아버지가 소켓 렌치를 넣어두던 케이스처럼 생겼고요

translation.en: [Bruce] Her neurosurgeon said he can't understand how this could possibly happen.
translation.ko: 집도한 신경외과의는 어떻게 그게 가능한지 이해할 수 없다고 했죠

translation.en: If somebody asked me to describe what the Midas Rex drill, uh, looked like,
translation.ko: 누군가가 제게 미다스 렉스 드릴의 모양을 설명해 달라고 하면

translation.en: I might very well use the term, "Like an electric toothbrush."
translation.ko: 저도 그 말을 당연히 쓰죠 '전동칫솔 닮았습니다'

translation.en: And describing them, uh, as if they were a socket wrench set,
translation.ko: 그리고 소켓 렌치 세트처럼 생겼다고 할 거고요

translation.en: uh, I think that's very appropriate.
Her ability to describe...
what went on during surgery is inconceivable to me,
translation.ko: 수술 중에 있었던 일을 그렇게 묘사하는 건

translation.en: considering the state that she was in.
Pam Reynolds was clinically dead.
This really challenges the idea that our consciousness, our minds,
translation.ko: 우리의 의식, 정신은 뇌가 만든다는 개념에 대한

translation.en: are created by the brain, because her brain was not functioning...
translation.ko: 엄청난 도전이었죠 그분의 뇌는 기능하지 않았지만

translation.en: and yet she had the most vivid experience of her life.
[Peter] How can people be conscious when they're unconscious?
translation.ko: 어떻게 사람들은 의식이 없는데 의식을 할 수 있죠?

translation.en: It's an oxymoron. It's ridiculous.
translation.ko: 그 말 자체가 모순이고 말이 안 됩니다

translation.en: But in fact, this is what the data seemed to prove more and more.
translation.ko: 하지만 테이터 상으로는 점점 많은 게 입증되고 있어요

translation.en: Well, that, of course, is going to have some significance
for our ideas about death.
I mean, is it possible
translation.ko: 우리가 죽을 때 의식이 확장한다는 게

translation.en: that there is an expansion of consciousness when we die?
translation.ko: 우리가 죽을 때 의식이 확장한다는 게 가능할까요?

translation.en: [woman 1] When one survives something so catastrophic as death
translation.ko: 사람이 죽음 같은 파국적인 것에서 살아남으면

translation.en: there's a gaping hole in your soul.
Inside, you feel like crumbling,
and you wonder, "How do I make sense of it?"
When people talk about near death experiences,
translation.ko: 사람들은 흔히 임사 체험을 즐거운 거로 묘사합니다

translation.en: they talk about it being so pleasant.
translation.ko: 사람들은 흔히 임사 체험을 즐거운 거로 묘사합니다 "스테퍼니 아널드"

translation.en: But it was not the case with me.
When I first met my husband, Jonathan, we definitely wanted to have children.
translation.ko: 남편 조너선과 처음 만났을 때 우린 아이들을 낳자고 했었어요

translation.en: We had our first, Adina. No issues, no complications.
translation.ko: 그렇게 해서 첫째 아디나가 아무 탈 없이 태어났죠

translation.en: Delivered her and back at work eight days later.
The second one was after seven rounds of IVF.
And everything went swimmingly until the 20-week ultrasound.
translation.ko: 모든 게 순조롭게 진행됐고 20주 차 초음파 검사를 받으러 갔죠

translation.en: They do the scan and they say, "Oh. You have a placenta previa."
Jonathan was with me and I said,
"I don't know what this is, but I've got a bad feeling about it."
And then I open the computer and I start Googling.
Placenta previa can turn into an accreta,
which is when the placenta marries itself to the uterus.
translation.ko: 그건 태반이 자궁벽에 완전히 붙어버리는 걸 말하죠

translation.en: If that happens, you could hemorrhage,
translation.ko: 그렇게 되면 출혈이 일어날 수 있고

translation.en: and if that happens, you and the baby could lose your life.
translation.ko: 출혈이 일어나면 아이와 산모는 목숨을 잃을 수 있어요

translation.en: I sat back, and I said...
"This is going to happen to us.
The only difference is the baby's going to survive."
translation.ko: '유일하게 다른 점은 아기는 살 거란 거야'

translation.en: [woman 2] And what did you think?
Uh, that it was stereotypical pregnancy hysteria.
translation.ko: 전형적인 임신 히스테리성 증상으로 봤죠 "조너선 아널드"

translation.en: Although I didn't quite put it in those terms.
Earlier in my life, I trained as an air force pilot, got my PhD in economics.
translation.ko: 전 일찍이 공군 조종사로 복무했고 경제학 박사 학위도 받았기에

translation.en: Data is core to my being.
I like to joke that I don't like to complicate things with words and feelings.
translation.ko: 농담 삼아 말하는데 말과 감정으로 문제를 복잡하게 만드는 것보다

translation.en: I'd much rather go with the data.
And we didn't have any empirical data,
so I had the stereotypical husband's response.
But I dressed it up in science, so that made it more sophisticated.
translation.ko: 대신 과학으로 포장했죠 더 정교해 보이도록요

translation.en: [Stephanie] It was so difficult trying to communicate about feelings
translation.ko: 보여줄 게 실재하지 않는 상황에서 그 감정과 예감에 대해 소통하는 건

translation.en: and this foreboding
translation.ko: 그 감정과 예감에 대해 소통하는 건

translation.en: when I didn't have something tangible to show.
I told Jonathan, "I do not know what to tell you,
other than the fact that I've got this intense feeling around this
translation.ko: '뭔가 나쁜 일이 일어날 것 같은 기분이'

translation.en: that something bad is about to happen.
If you saw me in Starbucks and you said, "Oh, how's the pregnancy going?"
translation.ko: 스타벅스 같은 데서 누가 '출산 준비는 잘돼 가요?' 하면

translation.en: I would literally say, "I'm going to die."
And my premonitions kept coming.
I was walking in the park.
I saw a dry fountain.
In mind's eye, the fountain was flowing and, all of a sudden, it turned to blood.
translation.ko: 근데 갑자기 물이 넘쳐 내려오더니 피로 변하는 상상이 들었죠

translation.en: And I felt my body hemorrhage.
I called Jonathan, said "Meet me at the emergency room."
He's frantic about it.
Doctors examining me, and they're like, "No, you're actually fine."
Jonathan's like, "Okay, it's a false alarm,"
translation.ko: 조너선은 괜찮다고 거짓 경보라고 했지만 전 이랬죠

translation.en: and I'm like, "No, this is a warning."
translation.ko: 조너선은 괜찮다고 거짓 경보라고 했지만 전 이랬죠 '이건 경고야'

translation.en: [woman] I've had other patients who've expressed concern,
but I would say Stephanie was the first patient that came forward and said,
"I'm seeing things very vividly that are scaring me to death."
translation.ko: "줄리 레빗, 의학박사 산부인과" '목숨을 위협하는 것들이 너무나 생생하게 보여요'

translation.en: I tried to acknowledge her fear, but also my role is to keep the calm.
translation.ko: 전 그녀의 두려움을 인정하려고 노력했지만 진정시키는 것 또한 저의 역할이었죠

translation.en: So I was concerned, but I wasn't necessarily panicked.
[Stephanie] The day that I go into labor...
I was in the kitchen, giving Adina breakfast.
translation.ko: 전 주방에서 아디나에게 아침을 주고 있었는데

translation.en: -All of a sudden, blood went everywhere. -[kettle whistling]
My nanny was here and I said, "Let's get in the car."
translation.ko: 함께 있던 보모에게 차에 타자고 말했고

translation.en: She jumped in the driver's seat.
I said, "Get out. I am driving."
And she's like, "Are you crazy? You're bleeding."
I'm like, "I've had many premonitions. Dying in a car accident was not one."
translation.ko: 많은 예감이 들었지만 차 사고로 죽는 건 없었다고 했죠

translation.en: Jonathan was in New York on one of his business trips.
[Jonathan] My wife called to say that she was on her way to the hospital
and to get to Chicago as fast as possible.
[Stephanie] I was acutely aware that it was the day I was gonna die.
translation.ko: 전 그날 죽을 거란 느낌이 강하게 들었어요

translation.en: The last thing I texted Jonathan was...
"You've made me the happiest woman in the world and...
translation.ko: '당신 덕분에 난 세상에서 가장 행복한 여자였어'

translation.en: please take care of this baby."
And then they wheel me into the room
that's going to give life to Jacob and take mine.
translation.ko: 제이컵에겐 생명을 주고 제게선 그걸 앗아갈 곳이었어요

translation.en: They put a curtain right in front of my face and prepare me for a C-section.
translation.ko: 제 얼굴 앞에 가림막이 쳐졌고 제왕절개 수술이 시작됐어요

translation.en: -[baby cries] -They deliver Jacob.
He's healthy, happy.
Seconds later, I flatline.
Everything came into a 3D movie
and I could actually see outside of my body.
translation.ko: 전 그걸 제 몸 밖에서 볼 수 있었어요

translation.en: My point of view was above my body and next to my body,
and I could see everything that was going on in the operating room.
I see the anesthesiologist by my feet.
translation.ko: 마취과 의사가 발 옆에 있는 것도 보였고

translation.en: I see which nurse jumped on my chest to give me CPR.
translation.ko: 어떤 간호사가 달려들어 심폐소생술을 하는지도 보였죠

translation.en: In this other dimension, spatial relations break.
translation.ko: 그 다른 차원에선 공간 관계가 깨져요

translation.en: -There is no ceiling. There are no walls. -[water rushing]
Everything is just moving around in so many different directions.
translation.ko: 모든 게 많은 방향으로 움직이기만 하죠

translation.en: I saw my daughter in a completely different part of the hospital
translation.ko: 병원의 완전히 다른 부분에서 보모와 함께 있던

translation.en: with our nanny.
I saw what my husband was wearing when he got off the plane.
translation.ko: 비행기에서 내린 남편이 무슨 옷을 입고 있는지도 봤고요

translation.en: And then I see spirits everywhere.
My grandmother, who had passed when I was ten years old.
My mother's brother also appeared.
The last thing I heard was Julie, Dr. Levitt,
translation.ko: 마지막으로는 레빗 박사가 말하는 소리를 들었어요

translation.en: saying, "This can't be happening. This can't be happening."
translation.ko: 마지막으로는 레빗 박사가 말하는 소리를 들었어요 '이럴 순 없어'

translation.en: [Julie] This was about as serious as it gets.
Stephanie was having an amniotic fluid embolism.
Many patients will die from this condition,
because they bleed to death.
And I, with my hands across my chest, with my gloves on, looked up, and I said,
translation.ko: 전 수술 장갑을 낀 채 가슴에 손을 얹고 올려다보며

translation.en: under my breath, "This cannot be happening."
She called it.
She knew that this was going to happen.
[Stephanie] After I heard Dr. Levitt, there was just this pulling in my stomach,
translation.ko: 레빗 박사님의 소리를 들은 후 누가 저의 배를 끌어당겼고

translation.en: and then I was back in my body.
I was clinically dead for 37 seconds.
I was in a medically-induced coma for six days.
I had kidney failure.
I had to learn how to walk again.
I had to learn how to talk.
It took me a long time to physically recover.
When I was clinically dead, I knew that something extraordinary had happened.
translation.ko: 임상적으로 죽었을 때 범상치않은 일이 일어났단 걸 전 알았어요

translation.en: But it ultimately had to go to the people who were present that day to validate it.
translation.ko: 하지만 그걸 입증하려면 그날 거기에 있었던 사람들을 찾아가야만 했죠

translation.en: [Julie] Stephanie and I met to talk about what had happened that day.
translation.ko: 스테퍼니와 전 그날의 일을 얘기하려고 만났어요

translation.en: I almost couldn't breathe.
There was absolutely no way that she was aware
translation.ko: 절대 알 수 없는 걸 스테퍼니가 알았거든요

translation.en: of who was standing to her left, who was standing to her right,
translation.ko: 본인의 왼쪽엔 누가 섰는지 오른쪽엔 누가 섰는지

translation.en: what I said, what other people said in the operating room.
translation.ko: 전 무슨 말을 했으며 다른 사람들은 뭐라고 했는지를요

translation.en: It makes me...
believe in more than just what we know as art and science.
translation.ko: 인문과 과학 이상의 것들이 있단 걸 전 믿게 됐어요

translation.en: My medical mind turns more to a spiritual place,
translation.ko: 저의 의료적인 생각은 영적인 것에 더 의지하는데

translation.en: which I don't think I was ever really aware of in the past.
It was a very...
real lesson that day.
-[Jonathan] How old was Jacob there? -[Stephanie] Not even a year.
translation.ko: 이때 제이컵이 몇 살이었지? 한 살도 안 됐었어

translation.en: -[Jonathan] Yeah. -[Stephanie] Not even a year.
[Stephanie] All of the doctors were like, "I don't have a medical explanation
translation.ko: 의사들은 전부 이랬죠 '난 임사 체험 혹은 예감에 대해'

translation.en: for the near-death experience or the premonitions."
But I look at them as a knowing.
translation.ko: 하지만 전 그들이 모르는 거라고 생각해요

translation.en: This knowing comes from someplace.
translation.ko: 그걸 알게 하는 건 어딘가에 있어요

translation.en: [Jonathan] I'm not in the category of true believer.
translation.ko: 전 진정한 신봉자라고는 할 수 없습니다

translation.en: But I accept that there's something else going on here,
translation.ko: 하지만 이곳에 뭔가가 일어나고 있단 건 인정해요

translation.en: some extra dimension of knowledge or cognition, uh... that my wife has.
translation.ko: 아내가 겪은 것처럼 인지 혹은 인식에 있어서의 부가적인 차원 말이죠

translation.en: So I believe-- I believe that she knew.
[woman] Stephanie.
It would have been much...
um, easier to go along those three months prior to flatlining if he had said that.
translation.ko: 진작 해줬더라면 죽기 전의 3개월을 더 수월하게 보낼 수 있었을 거예요

translation.en: I just felt I wasn't believed by the one person I need to believe me.
translation.ko: 절 믿어줘야 할 한 사람이 믿어주지 않는단 느낌이었죠

translation.en: By the one person who matters.
Everybody else can call me crazy, hormonal and stressed out and everything,
translation.ko: 모두가 절 미쳤다거나 호르몬, 스트레스 때문이라고 해도

translation.en: but it's the one person that I needed to protect me.
And it was-- it was hard.
All of us who are researchers or scientists,
and professors, academics and the like, um,
are engaged in research because we don't know everything.
translation.ko: 조사에 몰두하죠 모든 걸 다 알지 못하니까요

translation.en: And what this is telling me is that there's--
translation.ko: 그 일로 인해 알게 된 건

translation.en: Whether it's God or spirits
or some sense that we have that is not yet identified...
there is something like that that was operating here.
-[Bruce] Sit right there. -[Stephanie] Okay, great.
Right before flatline, I was perpendicular.
translation.ko: 죽기 직전에 전 수직으로 서 있었어요

translation.en: I know people talk about, like, floating -and being above their body. -[Bruce] Yeah.
translation.ko: 흔히 자신들의 몸 위에 뜬다는 얘기를 많이 하는데

translation.en: [Stephanie] I didn't have that.
So it's almost like you were in both places at once.
Part of you was still in the body
-and part of you was out there. -Yeah.
[Bruce] Most people who share their experiences with us
translation.ko: 사람들은 그걸 이해하는 데에 어려움을 겪기 때문에

translation.en: do so because they're struggling with how to understand it.
It doesn't make sense in terms of science or their particular religious background
and they're looking for some way to come to terms with it.
translation.ko: 그걸 받아들일 방법을 찾고 있는 거죠

translation.en: I just would like to understand -a little bit more about the mechanics. -Yeah.
translation.ko: 전 역학에 대해 좀 더 알아보고 싶은데요

translation.en: And is there a pattern that you're seeing
in people that have had near death experiences?
Yeah. Well, some things that you told-- told me about
are very common, but some are not.
translation.ko: 무척 흔한 거지만 일부는 그렇지 않아요

translation.en: Frankly, the premonitions that came before it are not common.
translation.ko: 솔직히 예감을 먼저 하는 건 흔치 않은 것입니다

translation.en: It's more common to have these premonitions after the experience.
translation.ko: 경험을 한 후에 그런 걸 겪는 게 더 흔하죠

translation.en: What struck me most about Stephanie's experience
is she was having premonitions
about dying for months before it happened.
And these were not imaginations. They were things she could not deny.
translation.ko: 그건 상상이 아니었고 거부할 수 없는 일이었죠

translation.en: There are all these things going on around us all the time
translation.ko: 우리 주변엔 항상 어느 정도는 차단할 수 있는 이런 일들이 일어나고 있어요

translation.en: that we sort of block out. It's like our brain has a filter
translation.ko: 어느 정도는 차단할 수 있는 이런 일들이 일어나고 있어요 뇌에 필터가 있어서

translation.en: that filters out things that don't help us get along in this world.
translation.ko: 세상을 사는 데에 보탬이 안 되는 것들을 걸러내 주죠

translation.en: And when something like a near death experience happens,
translation.ko: 그리고 임사 체험 같은 일이 일어나면

translation.en: that opens up the filter.
The door's been opened for you.
translation.ko: 그 문이 당신에게 계속 열려 있죠

translation.en: And once it's open, it's-- it's hard to shut it.
translation.ko: 문이 한 번 열리면 닫기가 힘듭니다

translation.en: [Stephanie] My visions and my premonitions have become more intense
since my near-death experience.
I believe it's a blessing.
But spiritually, it's a challenge, because...
I see things that people don't see a lot of the time.
translation.ko: 사람들이 못 보는 걸 보는 경우가 많거든요

translation.en: Most of the visions I get are from complete strangers.
Just people who are in my line of sight.
I feel like I'm gonna have a heart attack.
translation.ko: 심장이 멎을 것 같은 기분이 들어요

translation.en: But I know it's not mine.
We all have this ability to perceive things, especially danger.
translation.ko: 우린 누구나 일을 감지하는 능력이 있어요 특히 위험을요

translation.en: Um, we just don't take it seriously.
translation.ko: 다만 그걸 진지하게 안 받아드릴 뿐이죠

translation.en: What do you suggest to those who sit in this chair across from you
translation.ko: 이 의자에 박사님과 마주 앉아서 임사 체험을 설명하는 사람들에게

translation.en: and explain their near-death experiences?
translation.ko: 이 의자에 박사님과 마주 앉아서 임사 체험을 설명하는 사람들에게 어떤 말씀을 해주시나요?

translation.en: What do you normally advise them?
I can just tell you what I've learned
from the thousands of people who have sat in that chair and talked to me.
translation.ko: 수천 명의 사람들에게서 알게 된 걸 말씀드릴 순 있어요

translation.en: And what seems to be most comforting to them
is knowing, one, you're not alone.
translation.ko: 혼자가 아니란 사실을 알게 된 것이었어요

translation.en: Many people have had near death experiences.
And if we can't understand it,
we can at least have faith that there's a purpose to it.
translation.ko: 거기엔 이유가 있단 거에 대한 믿음은 적어도 있죠

translation.en: And you don't have to be in control of it,
because, in fact, we're not in control of it.
Something else is.
Thank you.
I used to be more easy-going before this all happened. Um...
translation.ko: 이 일이 생기기 전엔 훨씬 느긋한 사람이었어요

translation.en: I used to laugh more. Uh...
And...
I used to not take things so seriously.
translation.ko: 일을 썩 심각하게 받아들이는 사람이 아니었어요

translation.en: I-- I think Jonathan misses that part of me.
translation.ko: 조너선은 저의 그런 부분이 그리울 거예요

translation.en: I think I'll be asking questions probably until the day I die.
translation.ko: 전 아마 죽는 날까지 질문을 할 거예요

translation.en: Again.
[Jose] The experience is very, very difficult to process.
translation.ko: 그 경험을 처리하는 건 무척 힘들어요

translation.en: The dying is very difficult.
A few years after my experience, I started painting.
translation.ko: 임사 체험을 하고 몇 년 후 전 그림을 시작했습니다

translation.en: Had no idea. I'd never painted in my life.
Initially, it was just a desire to reproduce what I saw...
translation.ko: 처음엔 단순히 제가 본 걸 재현하고 싶었어요

translation.en: where I was in a ball of color...
and these colors were all moving, and I become the color.
translation.ko: 색깔들은 전부 움직였고 저도 그 색깔들이 됐어요

translation.en: That's how I wound up doing art.
Just a desire to try to create that three-dimensional feeling with color.
But as I kept doing it more and more,
I began to realize that it's a lot deeper than that.
translation.ko: 그건 훨씬 심오하단 걸 깨닫기 시작했죠

translation.en: It was healing.
It was healing me.
Dying is traumatic.
And it's difficult to integrate and-- and get past that.
translation.ko: 그것에 적응해서 잊고 나아가는 건 어렵습니다

translation.en: This world of art and color...
brought a lot of peace and calm into my life,
translation.ko: 제 삶에 많은 평화와 안정을 가져다주었어요

translation.en: and it made me feel a sense of knowing.
People ask me if the experience was real or not.
At the end of the day, I can't prove to you.
I can only share my experience with you.
[Mary] I had more motivation
than any other person on this planet to disprove my account.
translation.ko: 제 이야기가 틀렸다고 입증하고 싶은 사람입니다

translation.en: Because during my near-death experience, when I was with these beings...
translation.ko: 왜냐하면 임사 체험을 하며 그 존재들과 있는 동안

translation.en: they told me about the coming and unexpected death of my oldest son, Willie,
translation.ko: 제 큰아들 윌리가 돌연사할 거란 얘기를 들었거든요

translation.en: who was only nine years old at the time of my accident.
I knew that if I could come up with any other plausible explanation,
translation.ko: 그럴듯한 다른 설명을 제가 할 수만 있다면

translation.en: that I would be able to discount everything I'd been told.
translation.ko: 들었던 모든 걸 무시할 수 있을 거예요

translation.en: I wasn't given details in terms of the date and time of his death,
translation.ko: 사망일과 시간 같은 자세한 내용은 없었지만

translation.en: but it was very concrete information
translation.ko: 아이가 18세 전에 죽을 거라고 제가 생각하게 할 만큼

translation.en: that made me think he would never live to be 18.
translation.ko: 아이가 18세 전에 죽을 거라고 제가 생각하게 할 만큼 무척 구체적인 내용이었어요

translation.en: And...
I asked why.
You know, why...
Why Willie? Why my son?
And I was told that beauty comes of all things.
translation.ko: 그리고 들은 말은 아름다운 이가 먼저 온단 거였죠

translation.en: You can imagine how difficult it was
translation.ko: 매일 아침에 눈을 뜨면 그날이 혹시 아들이

translation.en: to wake up every day wondering if that would be the day that my son died.
translation.ko: 죽는 날은 아닌지 걱정하는 심정은 이루 말할 수 없이 힘들 거란 건 상상이 될 거예요

translation.en: I did not tell anyone about that...
translation.ko: 전 그것에 대해 누구에게도 말하지 않았어요

translation.en: until shortly before Willie's 18th birthday.
translation.ko: 그러다 윌리의 18세 생일을 목전에 둔 어느 날이 됐죠

translation.en: We were at a ski race...
and I knocked on Willie's hotel room door at about four in the morning...
translation.ko: 전 새벽 4시 무렵에 윌리의 호텔 방 문을 두드렸어요

translation.en: and told him.
[laughing] And he thought-- he thought I was crazy.
But I told him and he...
took it in stride.
So when he reached his 18th birthday, I relaxed.
I sort of thought the plan for his life had changed.
translation.ko: 아이의 삶에 대한 계획이 바뀌었나 보다 싶었어요

translation.en: About two years later...
Willie was at a ski camp in Maine.
translation.ko: 윌리는 메인주의 한 스키 캠프에 갔어요

translation.en: He was roller-skiing,
which is a cross-country, dry landform of skiing...
with a friend of his, and a...
car missed her and hit him and killed him instantly.
translation.ko: 차가 그 아이를 피하려다 아들을 쳤고 아들은 즉사했어요

translation.en: The world stopped.
My experience, uh, did not...
and does not protect me from grief.
I love...
I loved my son and continue to love him...
more than I can imagine.
But my near-death experience changes how I understand death.
translation.ko: 하지만 임사 체험으로 인해 죽음에 대해 다르게 이해하게 됐어요

translation.en: Death is not the final word and it's not the end.
translation.ko: 죽음은 마지막 단어도 아니고 끝도 아니에요

translation.en: Death is just the physical loss.
I know my son is...
somewhere. [laughs]
And I know that I'll see him again.
[Bruce] If it is true that consciousness is not solely dependent on the brain...
translation.ko: 의식이 오직 뇌와 관련된 게 아니란 말이 사실이면

translation.en: that raises the question,
"What happens to consciousness after we die?"
translation.ko: '우리가 죽은 후에 의식엔 어떤 일이 일어날까?'

translation.en: Can a consciousness continue after the death of the body
and communicate with people who are still alive?
When I was four, I used to see spirits. I'd get messages from them.
translation.ko: 전 4살 때 혼령들을 봤고 그들한테서 메시지를 받았죠

translation.en: So I'm hopin' you're gonna enjoy this evening.
There will be some laughter, there may be some tears,
translation.ko: 웃음도 있을 거고 눈물도 있을 거예요

translation.en: and I'll do my best to get as many messages out as is possible.
translation.ko: "샌드라 오하라, 영매" 전 최대한 많은 메시지를 받도록 해볼게요

translation.en: I would see people that other people couldn't see.
translation.ko: 전 다른 사람들이 못 보는 사람들을 보곤 했어요

translation.en: But I didn't realize that they were not living people.
translation.ko: 하지만 살아있는 사람들이 아니란 건 몰랐죠

translation.en: [woman] As mediums, we open ourselves up to the spirit world.
translation.ko: 우린 영매로서 우리 자신을 영적 세계에 활짝 엽니다

translation.en: We create a meeting space for both worlds to be united.
translation.ko: 두 세계가 합해질 수 있는 만남의 공간을 만들죠
